column2: Are there case categories only found in pronouns?
column7:
Oblique forms (traditionally called accusative, though the classification is problematic), e.g. ānəm 'me', 
tawe 'him/her'; originally they are pronouns with possessive  markers of the same person; they can take other case 
markers, e.g. ānəm-nəl (1SG.OBL-ABL) 'from me'.

column6:
However, there is a suffix -tal ~ -tāl traditionally classified as a privative derivational suffix (when used denominally) and the negative participle when used deverbally. But!
Denominal forms can also be used as indirect objects, e.g. neː-taːl χos oːl-əs (woman-PRIV long live-PST.3SG)
'(he) lived without a wife for a long time' (OUDB > northern mansi > 1239: 4). Thus one could in theory call this a case suffix too.

column2: Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Are there word-internal consonant clusters in syllable onset?
column6: In three-constituent consonant clusters, the first constituent is the coda of the previous, the second and third consonants are the onset of the next syllable, cf. Coda-maximalization.

column2: Are there consonant clusters in syllable coda?
column7: Only in monosyllabic words and in word-final syllables.

column2: Are there clusters of three or more consonants in a word between vowels?
column6: Three (or more) constituent clusters in stems are sporadic; they occur mostly in derivations or other affixed forms on morpheme boundaries. (In most cases a non-phonemic epenthetic schwa appears before the third or fourth constituent of non-homorganic clusters: njeːlǝm ‘tongue’ ⟶ njeːlm-ǝt tongue-pl, joxt-ǝs come-pst(.3sg) ⟶ joxt-sǝm come-pst.1sg.)

column2: Is there phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g. [k] vs. [kʷ])?
column5: tāk 'strong' vs. akʷ 'one', māχəm 'people' vs. āχʷtas 'stone'
column6: There is contrast between /k/ vs. /kʷ/, /χ/ vs. /χʷ/.
